title: A (not very) first lesson on ggplot 2 :)
text:
Preparation
I need to install the following packages:

Code# | eval: false
# install CRAN packages
pkg_install =   c("ggplot2", "tibble", "tidyr", "forcats", "purrr", "prismatic", "corrr", 
    "cowplot", "ggforce", "ggrepel", "ggridges", "ggsci", "ggtext", "ggthemes", 
    "grid", "gridextra", "patchwork", "rcartocolor", "scico", "showtext", 
    "shiny", "plotly", "highcharter", "echarts4r")
# install.packages(pkg_install)


I was facing the error of installing devtools

Code# | eval: false
# install from GitHub since not on CRAN
# install.packages('devtools')
# devtools::install_github("JohnCoene/charter")


I tried to update R to the latest version (commented the code as it would be run once)

Code# | eval: false
# update.packages(repos='http://cran.rstudio.com/', ask=FALSE, checkBuilt=TRUE)


â€“> Not worked
Oops I was should be using â€œâ€˜devtoolsâ€™â€ instead of â€œdevtoolsâ€!!! Problem solved
The Dataset
I was using the dataset: â€œNational Morbidity and Mortality Air Pollution StudyÂ (NMMAPS)â€
Install the readr first:

Code# | eval: false
# install.packages('readr')


Import data
â€œ: :â€ here call the namespace and can be used to access a function without loading the package.

Codechic <- readr::read_csv("https://cedricscherer.com/data/chicago-nmmaps-custom.csv")

Rows: 1461 Columns: 10
â”€â”€ Column specification â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Delimiter: ","
chr  (3): city, season, month
dbl  (6): temp, o3, dewpoint, pm10, yday, year

The {ggplot2} Package
A ggplot is built up from a few basic elements:

Data;
Geometries geom_: the geometric shape that will represent the data;
Aesthetics aes_: aesthetics of the geometric or statistical objects, such as postition, color, size, shape, and transparency;
Scales scale_: map between the data and the aesthetics dimensions, such as data raneg to plot width or factor values to colors;

Reference
Source: https://www.cedricscherer.com/2019/08/05/a-ggplot2-tutorial-for-beautiful-plotting-in-r/
